Message.Title: Amazon prepping a smartphone and four new tablets....Yes, four not one
Message.Msg: Amazon will unveil a second-generation Kindle Fire in July, and now the NPD analyst Richard Shim says three 7-in. Kindle Fire 2 models and one 8.9-in. Kindle Fire 2 model are going into production in August. One would have a 1,024 x 600 display with no camera, a second would have a 1,280 x 800 display with a camera the third would have a 1280 x 800 display with a camera and a 4G radio atop Wi-Fi. The 8.9-in. model of the Kindle Fire 2 would have a 1,920 x 1,200 display, Shim didn't any share pricing plans for the coming upgrades in his report. The sub-$200 price-point is considered ideal by many manufacturers, and Google's first tablet, the Nexus 7, is set to go on sale in mid-July for $199. and Google's Nexus 7 has a 1280 x 800 display resolution also $200 too

Topic.Title: Considering going all in short apple

Message.Msg: Apple has about 36,000 registered shareholders; that's one shareholder for every 1000 iPhones sold just in the last quarter. If all 240million+ iPhone users bought just on share each, that would soak up 25% of existing Apple shares and drive the price up by hundreds of dollars per share. Clearly you have no clue.

Topic.Title: Amazon prepping a smartphone and four new tablets....Yes, four not one

Message.Msg: If Amazon does come out with four models, only the 1024x600 model sans camera (same specs as current model) will sell at $199. The others will be priced higher. The reason the existing Fire sold so well is because, at it's low price people who would not otherwise spring for a tablet were willing to give the tablet experience a shot at that price. Plus a lot of folks saw it as a means to give a Christmas gift that represents cool tech (a tablet device) at a price that wouldn't break the bank. Neither of these purchase scenarios imply people felt it was a better tablet than iPad, rather, it merely represented a unique opportunity. From the reported Fire sales slump in the quarter immediately following the holiday quarter, you can surmise that the gift-giving motivation was the more significant driver of the Fire's early sales success. Who is to say that those who received a Fire for Christmas were thrilled with their present; I bet many would much rather have received an iPad under the tree. And I'll further bet that a lot of those gifted Fires will be re-gifted this coming holiday season and throughout the year at every birthday and other occasion that presents an opportunity to those who received an unwanted cheap tablet to dump it off in lew of spending hard-earned money on a new gift. Now, add an iPad mini into the mix, running any of the 225,000+ available apps and with an Apple logo on the back (signifying Apple quality built-in) and a larger display, at 7.85", and aimed at the education market, at an attractive price (maybe $279 for 16GB or $329 for 32GB) and you can begin to do that math on how many fewer Of the low-end Fire's will be sold during this year's holiday quarter. Who's going to get their kid a Fire when they can send him/her to school with the tablet that the school recommends and supports for classroom use, study guides, homework submission, quiz and test-taking, etc? NEXT!

Message.Title: Amazon Might Introduce A Smartphone In Partnership With Foxconn, Potential Competition To Apple
Message.Msg: Posted by Joshua on July 8, 2012 in Featured, Industry Headlines According to sources, Amazon is all set to compete with Google and Apple in the smartphone market by developing their own device in partnership with Foxconn. Currently, Nokia, Microsoft, Sony, Apple and Samsung are a few of Foxconn’s customers. Amazon’s device will compete with Apple’s iPhone and devices running on Google’s Android. Introducing their own smartphone will help Amazon earn revenue from services offered by them like digital books, movies and songs through devices that are low priced. Amazon could find itself a niche in the market for advanced wireless devices even as Apple and Samsung dominate the business, managing to ship 398.4 million smartphones already in the first quarter of this year. Amazon’s spokesman, Drew Herdener, did not comment on the issue.

Topic.Title: read asymco "building and dismantling windows"... very scare for msft

Message.Msg: "If we consider all the devices Apple sells, the whittling becomes even more significant and the multiple drops to below 2. Seen this way, Post-PC devices wiped out of leverage faster than it was originally built. They not only reversed the advantage but cancelled it altogether. Considering the near future, it’s safe to expect a “parity” of iOS+OS X vs. Windows within one or two years. The install base may remain larger for some time longer but the sales rate of alternatives will swamp it in due course. The consequences are dire for Microsoft. The wiping out of any platform advantage around Windows will render it vulnerable to direct competition. This is not something it had to worry about before. Windows will have to compete not only for users, but for developer talent, investment by enterprises and the implicit goodwill it has had for more than a decade. It will, most importantly, have a psychological effect. Realizing that Windows is not a hegemony will unleash market forces that nobody can predict." - asymco

Topic.Title: option symbol help

Message.Msg: I tried to look for the explanation and couldn't find it. I don't think Rod is right since they both have the same expiration date, Aug 18 2012. Proper option symbols have three zeros following the strike price (these are used if strike price has decimal value related to prior splits). It appears that symbols with only two zeros at the end (after the strike price) no longer trade. Maybe its a relic related to the change in sybolology in 2010?

Topic.Title: Amazon prepping a smartphone and four new tablets....Yes, four not one

Message.Msg: Apple has to be LOVING this development. Adding 4 more pseudo-tablets into the runners-up market that lack an ecosystem is about the best news Apple could receive. Sure, some of these will sell, but when Apple introduces *their* smaller tablet, and people see how it syncs with their phone, Apple PC, Apple laptop, iPad and iTV, those that own these pseudo-tablets will feel extremely shortchanged. These products serve as nothing more than free advertising for Apple. And these dummies actually LOSE money on these products while doing so. Great business models! Granted, I do understand in Amazon's case it's simply more of a "loss leader," but they're really the lone exception. And I still think it's silly to lose money, rather than make some or break even. It really signifies that you simply have zero confidence in your product as a stand alone device.

Topic.Title: Battery test...,Galaxy S3 was #1 provide 726 minutes call time iPhone 4S was #4 with a decent 467 minutes

Message.Msg: Call time? Call time? What a lame test! All of the tested phones will have to get plugged in LONG before that because the leading battery drain is usage for DATA, especially the 4G devices like the winner. Unless you are only going to use these devices as a phone, of course the unit with the largest battery wins. Call time. Sheesh. That's like testing cars for their MPG but only letting them idle, not actually drive. Thompson

Message.Title: Samsung Galaxy S3 best for mobile battery lifeLasts 259 minutes longer than the iPhone on calls
Message.Msg: Samsung Galaxy S3 best for mobile battery lifeLasts 259 minutes longer than the iPhone on calls 05 July 2012 Samsung Galaxy S3 battery The Samsung Galaxy S3, Samsung's latest top-of-the-range smartphone, has the best battery life of any smartphone in Which? testing history. The new phone, which is Samsung's answer to the iPhone 4S, managed 726 minutes of calls on medium 3G reception, 91 minutes better than the next best model - the HTC One X - and 168 minutes more than the iPhone 4S. It remains to be seen if the Apple iPhone 5, the sixth-generation iPhone, will reclaim the top-spot, but for the moment it's Samsung that can lay claim to the crown of longest lasting smartphone. Read our full Samsung Galaxy S3 review to see how the phone performs overall, and see our mobile phone reviews to compare it to other handsets from all the major manufacturers. And if you're struggling with the battery life on your phone, read our top 5 ways to improve your phone battery life on Which? Tech Daily.

Message.Title: Manipulating Libor rates. = Game over
Message.Msg: (Reuters) - Two Deutsche Bank employees have been suspended after it used external auditors to examine whether staff were involved in manipulating interbank lending rates, German magazine Der Spiegel reported, citing no sources. A spokesman for Deutsche Bank on Sunday declined to comment on the article, referring to its quarterly report, which said it has received subpoenas and requests for information from U.S. and European authorities in connection with setting interbank rates. On Friday, people familiar with the matter told Reuters that Germany's markets regulator has launched a special probe into Deutsche Bank over suspected manipulation of interbank lending rates. Investigators in the United States, Europe and Japan are examining more than a dozen big banks over suspected rigging of the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor). Britain's Barclays has been the only bank to admit wrongdoing, agreeing last week to pay a fine of more than $450 million. The Libor rates, compiled from estimates by large banks of how much they believe they have to pay to borrow from each other, are used to determine interest rates on trillions of dollars worth of contracts around the world. A spokesman for Frankfurt-based private bank Metzler said one of its investment companies has joined a number of class action suits in New York against banks accused of manipulating Libor rates. "This is a standard procedure," he said.

Topic.Title: option symbol help

Message.Msg: You really opened a can of worms here...lol !!! The 16.80 calls do exist for Aug. 18th for 625 stock price. This is the 'monthly' one, as the expiration is technically the 18th, being a Saturday. That premium is correct as of this moment.
